definition: name of disease in TCM
superficial syndrome/illness that has not attacked the vital organs of the human body
one of the channels of TCM
"eight principles," a method of giving a general description and syndrome differentiation (TCM)
damp heat/summer fever (TCM)
pattern-syndrome identification based on the eight principles (TCM)
pathogeny (cause of disease) in TCM/as opposed to vital energy 正氣|正气[zheng4 qi4]
interpretation of the cause/onset and process of an illness/pathogenesis
(TCM) the three truncal cavities (thoracic, abdominal and pelvic), known as the "triple heater" or "San Jiao"
term in TCM describing the progress of disease as an opposition between vital energy 正氣|正气[zheng4 qi4] and pathogeny 邪氣|邪气[xie2 qi4]
typhoid
wuling powder (decoction of poria mushroom used in TCM)/poria five powder/Hoelen five powder/five ling powder
pathogenic influence (TCM)
pulse taken at the wrist (TCM)
stagnation of 氣|气[qi4] (TCM)
(TCM) six excesses causing illness, namely: excessive wind 風|风[feng1], cold 寒[han2], heat 暑[shu3], damp 濕|湿[shi1], dryness 燥[zao4], fire 火[huo3]
